docs.lead_paragraph: A disclaimer: I do not own stock in Starbucks nor, to my knowledge, in any other company that sells coffee or its accouterments. I last wrote about America's most popular beverage four years ago, and the latest and largest study to date supports that earlier assessment of coffee's health effects. Although the new research, which involved more than 400,000 people in a 14-year observational study, still cannot prove cause and effect, the findings are consistent with other recent large studies.

headline.main: Personal Health: Having Your Coffee and Enjoying It Too

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses latest research on the health benefits of drinking coffee. Drawing (M)

headline.main: Really? The Claim: Eating Soy Increases the Risk of Breast Cancer
headline.print_headline: Really? The Claim: Eating soy increases the risk of breast cancer.

docs.abstract: The phytoestrogens in soy products can mimic the behavior of estrogen, a hormone that fuels many breast cancers. But studies have found that the fear is unfounded.
docs.snippet: The phytoestrogens in soy products can mimic the behavior of estrogen, a hormone that fuels many breast cancers. But studies have found that the fear is unfounded.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate is rightly demanding a full accounting of the damage from next year’s brutal sequester.

headline.seo: Lift the Veil on the Spending Cuts
headline.main: Lift the Veil on the Spending Cuts
headline.print_headline: Lift the Veil on the Spending Cuts

docs.abstract: Editorial expresses support for a Senate bill that would require a detailed accounting of exactly what programs will be cut under the $1.2 trillion sequester mandated by the law that ended the debt-ceiling fight in 2011; contends that the best way to shock both parties into coming up with a balanced, long-term deficit-reduction plan is to let the public see the awful details of the alternative.
docs.snippet: The Senate is rightly demanding a full accounting of the damage from next year’s brutal sequester.

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers found no evidence that children who received active video games were more active than children who received games that were more passive.

headline.seo: ‘Active’ Video Games Don’t Make Youths More Active

docs.abstract: Randall Stross Digital Domain column examines study in journal Pediatrics that found no evidence that children who play active video games were more active than children who play games that were more passive; notes pediatrician's observation that changing sedentary behavior is extremely difficult.
docs.snippet: Researchers found no evidence that children who received active video games were more active than children who received games that were more passive.

docs.lead_paragraph: When the government placed restrictions on repairs to pipes on federal land, a volunteer posse set out to do the work by hand and make a point about a storied Arizona town.

headline.main: With Wild West Spirit, Tombstone Fights for Its Water
headline.print_headline: With Wild West Spirit, Tombstone Fights for Its Water

docs.abstract: Volunteers hike into Coronado National Forest in Arizona and move by hand boulders that disrupted lines funneling water from mountain springs into the storied town of Tombstone; government had placed restrictions on repairs to pipes on federal land, due to concerns of the precarious state of the forest and its wildlife.
docs.snippet: When the government placed restrictions on repairs to pipes on federal land, a volunteer posse set out to do the work by hand and make a point about a storied Arizona town.

docs.lead_paragraph: This column appears in the June 24 issue of The New York Times Magazine. The average person makes more than 200 decisions about food every day, and most of the time isn't even aware of it. We may take a stand each morning when it comes to ordering a tall, nonfat, no-foam latte, but for the most part, we tend to consume what's put in front of us. When we eat out, everything from a restaurant's lighting to the menu design to the size of the plate or cup influences how much we eat and drink.

headline.main: How Can a Big Gulp Look So Small?

docs.abstract: Tara Parker-Pope Well column examines research that has been done on whether consumers can perceive serving sizes accurately, in light of New York City Mayor Michael R Bloomberg's proposed ban on supersize soft drinks. Drawings, Charts (M)4

headline.main: Going to the Fat Farm With Dad

docs.abstract: As a child, I spent a month with my father at a "fat farm" in Durham, N.C., and gained a new appreciation for what was missing from my family life.
